Class oracle.plsql.PStringBuffer

Class oracle.plsql.PStringBuffer 

java.lang.Object
   |
   +----oracle.plsql.PValue
           |
           +----oracle.plsql.PStringBuffer
public class PStringBuffer
extends PValue
This class encapsulates PL/SQL strings: char, varchar2 and long. It is implemented to look like java.lang.StringBuffer as closely as possible. However, one key difference is that the capacity of a PStringBuffer indicates the number of bytes, not Java chars, allocated to store the string as this PStringBuffer is used to store PL/SQL char, varchar2 and long. Also, the strings will be converted to the NLS character set currently selected in oracle.lang.NLS.
See Also:
StringBuffer, setCurrentCharSet

PStringBuffer(int)
Constructs a null PL/SQL StringBuffer of a specific capacity (bytes).
PStringBuffer(int, String)
Constructs a PL/SQL StringBuffer and initialize with the given String.

Constructs a PL/SQL StringBuffer and initialize with the given String.
PStringBuffer(int, StringBuffer)
Constructs a PL/SQL StringBuffer and initialize with the given StringBuffer.

Returns the capacity of this PStringBuffer (in terms of bytes).

PStringBuffer

                       String str)

Parameters:

str - the initial value of the PStringBuffer
PStringBuffer 
  public PStringBuffer(String str)
Constructs a PL/SQL StringBuffer and initialize with the given String. The capacity of the StringBuffer is equal to the length of the String.
Parameters:
str - the initial value of the PStringBuffer
PStringBuffer 
  public PStringBuffer(int length,
                       StringBuffer str)
Constructs a PL/SQL StringBuffer and initialize with the given StringBuffer. The content of this PStringBuffer is initialized with that of the given StringBuffer.
Parameters:
capacity - the capacity of the PStringBuffer (bytes)
str - the StringBuffer to initialize with

useBuffer 
  public void useBuffer(boolean use)
Specifies whether this buffer should be used directly in PL/SQL execution. Default is false. This may speed up the performance of PL/SQL execution by minimizing memory copy. However, if the same PL/SQL procedure or function is used repeatedly with different buffers, it will perform better by not using this buffer. In such a case, the wrapper class will allocate its own buffer to serve all calls.
Parameters:
use - use this buffer or not
